Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Understanding Multi-spacecraft Observations of Solar Energetic Particle Events in Terms of Global Disturbances in the Solar Corona and Heliospheric Magnetic Field Connection
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this three-year SHINE project, the PI aims to investigate the relationship between global disturbances from the solar corona and the angular spread of Solar Energetic Particle (SEP) events, in order to advance present understanding of when, where and how these particles are accelerated and released. The project team examine Extreme Ultra Violet (EUV) images taken by SDO and STEREO in comparison with coronagraph data from STEREO and SOHO to trace the global coronal disturbances into coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and associated shock waves. For 20 to 30 near-relativistic electron events (with and without large angular spread), the team will look for significant differences in the properties of global coronal disturbances and lack thereof. The team will compare the observed onset times of electron events at STEREO and near the Earth with the times at which the global coronal disturbances and CME-driven shocks intersect field lines connecting to observers at the respective spacecraft. The SEP onsets can also be influenced by the interplanetary magnetic field, which may deviate from the Parker spiral. The team will analyze solar wind data from STEREO, near the Earth, and at other locations in the inner heliosphere, to estimate the effective path length the particles experience and additionally to understand the origin of non-Parker-spiral field. The research agenda is supplemented by running heliospheric simulations at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) with customized boundary conditions to probe macroscopic disturbances in solar wind. Furthermore, the team will investigate the associated SEP ion data in perspective to address the distinction between impulsive and gradual SEP events in terms of the processes near the Sun and in the interplanetary space.

The project team aims to improve present understanding of SEP events by adopting a cross-disciplinary approach that addresses both solar and interplanetary in-situ data as important elements, and includes numerical simulations. This project has the potential of changing the prevalent view of the origins of SEP events in a major way, and thus eventually give societal benefit of correctly predicting SEP events. The team will disseminate the project results at various meetings including SHINE workshops, in refereed journals, and through the Heliophysics Event Knowledge-base developed at the PI's institution. The research agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to investigate the possible role of EUV waves in the acceleration and transport of solar energetic particle (SEP) events. For solar cycle 23 events, there was no consensus as to whether EUV waves could be used as representing acceleration regions when we tried to understand the onset behavior of SEP events. This was largely because of the limitations of the instrument (SOHO/EIT) that captured EUV waves.  Therefore we tackled similar problems using SEP events in solar cycle 24 as EUV waves and other low coronal signatures of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) have been better observed by SDO/AIA, thanks largely to its higher cadence and broad temperature coverage.  Moreover, the twin STEREO spacecraft provide additional view points of solar eruptions in EUV and white-light images as well as solar wind and SEPs in in situ data at widely separate longitudes, giving us great opportunities to understand the possible relation of the SEP onsets and EUV waves.

We first found the close association of EUV waves with gradual SEP events (and some impulsive SEP events as well), especially those that were observed by multiple heliographic longitudes. One of the central questions was to see if the EUV wave traverses the footpoint of the magnetic field that connects to the observer around the time of the SEP release.  In most cases we found that this was not the case.  The EUV wave arrived either too early or too late, and it often disappeared before reaching the well-connected area.  This was basically unchanged even after we tried to bring out the diffuse wave, using the techniques that included spatial and temporal summing, edge enhancement, and so on. From this result we conclude that EUV waves provide almost no clue as to the SEP release even though they often accompany wide-spread SEP events.  Consequently, the usual assumption may also be questioned that the EUV wave tracks the bottom of a CME-driven shock, suggesting a less intimate relationship between EUV waves and CMEs than is generally conceived.

The onset of high-energy SEP events, electrons in particular, may be dominated by scatter-free particles, and therefore may provide a snapshot of the magnetic field connection from the Sun to the observer at L1 or STEREO. This is true as long as the heliosphere is not disturbed by prior disturbances. We thus studied the evolution of the heliospheric magnetic field and solar wind plasma up to the individual SEP events, making sure that they were not affected by ICMEs or strong stream interaction regions (SIRs) due to high speed solar wind streams. Overall, we have come to a conclusion that the SEP onset could be explained in terms of the connection of the observer to the CME-driven shock (whether or not its low part is observed as an EUV wave), but cannot rule out the possible contribution of cross field diffusion especially when the SEP release is delayed for more than an hour from the eruption as marked by a type III radio burst. Moreover, in several events SEPs started too early before the observer establishes connection to the shock.  Sometimes, it appears that the observer never establishes the connection. This in turn indicates significant uncertainties in our understanding of the heliospheric magnetic field, which may not be surprising given that magnetic field is measured reasonably on only much less than a half of the solar surface.

Our achievements that concern intellectual merit consist of analyzing SDO/AIA data to examine EUV waves in the context of SEP events, which led us to conclude that they do not provide key information on the acceleration region. Secondly, we found that events with a longer delay may not always be explained in terms of CME-driven shocks, whose lower parts sometimes but not always trace EUV waves. This points to the importance of cross field diffusion, but we did not find observational signatures in situ data at 1 AU that may be characteristic to such a process.  Our achievements that concern broader impacts may include the finding that heliospheric magnetic field is not properly modeled, which includes state-of-the-arts MHD simulations. This may help us prioritize the architecture of heliospheric sentinels that will hopefully materialize in near future.
